docs.snippet: The sending away of the families of the officers and men at Fort Sumter, in anticipation of a possible attack, was announced by telegraph several days since. Yesterday the steamer Marion arrived from Charleston, having among her passengers these...

headline.main: FROM FORT SUMTER.; THE WOMEN AND CHILDREN SENT AWAY. THEIR ARRIVAL AT THIS PORT ON BOARD THE MARION CONDITION OF THE GARRISON. THE FORCE IN THE FORT. PROVISIONS.

docs.lead_paragraph: The sending away of the families of the officers and men at Fort Sumter, in anticipation of a possible attack, was announced by telegraph several days since. Yesterday the steamer Marion arrived from Charleston, having among her passengers these persons, fifty-six in all, twenty-five of them being children.

docs.snippet: Mr. GRANT presented a petition for the submission of the Crittenden amendment to the people.
docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. GRANT presented a petition for the submission of the Crittenden amendment to the people.

docs.snippet: The Peace Convention was opened with prayer by Rev. Dr. GURLEY, when the Committee on Organization reported as follows:

headline.main: Proceedings of the Peace Conference.; SPEECH OF EX-PRESIDENT JOHN TYLER. Good Effects of the Union Triumph in Virginia.INTERESTING PROCEEDINGS OF CONGRESS.Passage of the $25,000,000 Loan Billin the Senate.Scathing Anti-Secession Speech by Mr.Johnson, of Tennessee.Withdrawal of the LouisianaDelegation in the House.Mr. Bouligny Refuses to Secede andAnnounces his Intention to Stand by the Union.LATEST DISPATCHES FROM THE SOUTH.Proceedings of the MontgomeryConvention.OUR WASHINGTON DISPATCHES. SPEECH OF EX-PRESIDENT TYLER. DOINGS OF THE PEACE CONVENTION. THE PRESIDENT'S JUDICIAL NOMINATIONS. SENATOR JOHNSON'S SPEECH ITS EFFECT. MR. BOULIGNY REFUSES TO SECEDE. VIRGINIA FOR THE UNION. MR. KELLOGG'S COMPROMISE INDORSED. WILL CONGRESS COMPROMISE? MORE ADMINISTRATION BACK-BONE. ANOTHER SECESSION CHAMPION. THE NAVY YARD SURRENDERS. M'CORMICK'S PATENT SCHEME CHECKED. CHEAP COINAGE. OPPOSITION TO THE MORRILL TARIFF. MEXICAN AFFAIRS SOUTHERN TELEGRAPHIC ARRANGEMENTS. DISPATCH TO THE ASSOCIATED PRESS.

docs.snippet: Recorder HOFFMAN opened this Court yesterday, with the following charge to the Grand Jury, of which Mr. Robert S. Hone was made foreman:

headline.main: Court of General Sessions.; CHARGE TO THE GRAND JURY.

docs.lead_paragraph: Recorder HOFFMAN opened this Court yesterday, with the following charge to the Grand Jury, of which Mr. Robert S. Hone was made foreman:

docs.snippet: The delegates to the Peace Convention, called at the suggestion of the Virginia Legislature, assembled at Washington yesterday, and effected a temporary organization, by the selection of Mr. J. C. WRIGHT, of Ohio, as President, and Mr. H.E. WARD, of...
docs.lead_paragraph: The delegates to the Peace Convention, called at the suggestion of the Virginia Legislature, assembled at Washington yesterday, and effected a temporary organization, by the selection of Mr. J. C. WRIGHT, of Ohio, as President, and Mr. H.E. WARD, of Maryland, as Secretary.

docs.snippet: The following report from Ex-President TYLER, the Commissioner sent by the General Assembly of Virginia to President BUCHANAN, to request him to abstain from any further military demonstrations against the South, was transmitted to both Houses of the...

headline.main: Ex-President Tyler's Report of His Mission to Washington.

docs.lead_paragraph: The following report from Ex-President TYLER, the Commissioner sent by the General Assembly of Virginia to President BUCHANAN, to request him to abstain from any further military demonstrations against the South, was transmitted to both Houses of the Legislature of that State on Wednesday:

docs.snippet: Mr. CRAFT presented a petition from WM. CULLEN BRYANZ and others asking the repeal of the law creating the office of City Judge in New-York, and complaining of the mal-administration of criminal jurisdiction in the City.
docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. CRAFT presented a petition from WM. CULLEN BRYANZ and others asking the repeal of the law creating the office of City Judge in New-York, and complaining of the mal-administration of criminal jurisdiction in the City.

docs.snippet: Mr. CRITTENDEN, of Kentucky, (Am.,) presented several memorials from citizens of various States in favor of the Crittenden resolutions.

headline.main: CONGRESSIONAL PROCEEDINGS.; SENATE. THE NATIONAL TROUBLES.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. CRITTENDEN, of Kentucky, (Am.,) presented several memorials from citizens of various States in favor of the Crittenden resolutions.
